Tools - Regex

Created:2019-03-01  Last modified:2019-03-01

  • Introduction
  • Rules
  • References

  1. Introduction

    A regular expression (regex) is a sequence of characters that define a search pattern.

    The pattern is constructed with logic.

    Rules

    1. wildcard: . matches any character, but only match one.
    2. boolean or: |
      "hello|hi" => hello, hi
    3. character classes: a special character matches a set of characters.
      \w matches alphanumeric characters plus "_", \d matches all digitals, \s matches space
      \W matches all characters except \w (\w|\W) = .
      user-defined character class with []:
      [aqsx] matches a|q|s|x
      [^aqsx] matches all except a|q|s|x
      [a-n] matches all a to n characters
    4. grouping: () create a group, \1 capture the first parenthese-delimited express
      "h(ello|i)" => hello|hi => hello, hi
      "(hi){2,3}" => hihi, hihihi

      \1

      e.g. "Hello, Hello" will match H(ello|i),\sH\1, the first group matched "ello", then the \1 will be "ello"
      H(ello|i),\sH(ello|i) != H(ello|i),\sH\1, because the first one also matches "Hello, Hi"
    5. Lookaround
    6. quantification (specify the expected number of repeat): *, ?, +, {}
      * matches 0 or more, ? matches 0 or 1, + match one or more, {3} exactly three, {3, 5} match 3 - 5, {1, } one or more, {,4} four or less.
      "qin{0,2}an" => qian|qinan|qinnan
      "q\w*" => q....
      ".*" => match anything
    7. anchor (specify a position in the string):^ start position of the string, $ end position of the string, \b word boundary (two end of a word), \B non-word boundary
      ^q => q,
      ^q.* => q, q....
      ^\w.* => must start with a \w
      q$ => q
      .*q$ => ...q
      ^q\w*n$ => q...n

      word boundary

      e.g. "How are you?" word boundary will be "H...w...a...e...y...u"
      \bH.* matches "How are you?"
      \ba.*e\b matches "are"
      \ba.*u\b matches "are you"

  2. Rules

    1. "abc": exactly match "abc"
    2. "ab[a-c]": match aba, abb, abc

  3. References

    1. https://regexr.com
    2. Regex Lookaround
